newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO seen soft, US second attack ignored.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO seen soft, US second attack ignored.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices were expected to end steady to soft in correction after the latest hike in prices caused by the rising U.S/Iraq tension, traders said on Wednesday.
They said the market is unmoved by the second round of missile attacks by the U.S. on Wednesday.
A bid for 180-centistoke cargo was seen for September 19-23 loading cargo from Singapore at $112.50 per tonne against an offer seen at $116. Levels were lower from Tuesday's $113-$116 per tonne.
Traders said the market has jumped too high on Tuesday on news that U.S had launched its first round of missile attacks on Iraq.
Traders said September paper was bid/asked at $110.75/$111.75 down from Tuesday's $113/$114.5.
Traders said cash levels are likely to track paper prices to end shade softer.
They said physical fundamentals remained unchanged with demand still seen from India and China. Traders expected more Mideast supplies to arrive in the second half of September.
But they said the market would remain watchful on the U.S/Iraq tensions. --Singapore newsroom (65-870-3082)
